So I know that you deliberately asked the question, because you wanted me to answer it very crisply and so with that what I'm really saying is that you're probably going through a cycle here due to a number of factors that will last one to two quarters and I think that if you look out over next fiscal year and beyond, you'll see growth in the mid-teens or above as the most likely scenario with all the appropriate caveats.
Jim, you have some tough comparables at Scientific-Atlanta as an example, maybe you'd spent a moment on that?

Well, I think, if you look at 7/07 last year, which was really the unbundled security. We started to see the orders roll in in Q2, but last year in Q3 of '07 is where our orders peak. So, for us this by far was going to be the most difficult comparable year year-over-year. So obviously, we pulled the number down quite a bit in this thing as we go through it. But as you look at it what we saw after Q3 is, we saw a drop off in our orders in Q4 getting much back more to normal. So we would anticipate that clearly this was by far the most difficult quarter for us to compare against on an order basis...
And next quarter it might be difficult on revenue.
...and next quarter will be the most difficult from a revenue standpoint as this bubble moves through the systems with the sales actually delayed behind the bookings by about one quarter.
Very good.

Well, you can add another thing there too. When you just look at service provider broadly after 12 quarters in terms of bookings growth in the U.S. of over 20%, naturally we are running into some of those though comps now. And so that all plays out over time and to John's message about over the long term given the relationships we have in place. As we go up against those tough comps, it's natural that those numbers come up about the same time, some of the edge technology hits the market. So there is a lot to be optimistic about as you look longer term.

I'll make no decisions on this month, this quarter or even this year. I feel very, very comfortable with where we are in service providers looking out over the next two, three, five years. So thank you very much.
Thanks, Ittai. Okay, next question please.
Thank you, our next question comes from Paul Mansky with Citigroup.

Actually most of mine have been asked and answered. However just kind of following up on that last question. Maybe just to provide some additional context, do you have offhand what your order growth would have looked like in North America service provider ex-Scientific-Atlanta?

No. I probably would have to sort it out, because remember service providers in North America this quarter last year grew, if I remember the numbers right 33% in terms of orders. So it was a crunching quarter in terms of the direction, Scientific-Atlanta orders grew --
This quarter versus previous quarter, we were slightly negative.
Slightly negative.
On a year-over-year basis. So you can look at that as a mechanism to try to judge ours you know about what ours are running.
But the comps on both sides, Paul, were really tough, really good last year in service provider in terms of the balance.
Certainly. Great. Thank you.
Thanks. Next question please.
Thank you, our next question comes from Simona Jankowski with Goldman Sachs.

Yes, hi, thank you. John, I just wanted to ask you as a follow-up to some of the comments you made in your prepared remarks about taking advantage of downturns to move into market adjacencies. Can you just expand on that as far as your organic numbers and also what you might be thinking about in terms of acquisitions? Why does this present an opportunity and where do you see yourself going strategically?

Yeah. One of the reasons and thank you for the question that we are going to continue to remain very aggressive in terms of our expenses, we could obviously cut back any time and improve the bottom line pretty quickly. We are moving into many new markets in each of the customer segments and by the way in most of the key geographies at the same time as well as going into market adjacencies and you don't see the results, especially in terms of the engineering investments for often three to five years after that. We have the internal start-up engine really cranking and in fairness, this might be the first hi-tech company that's been able to do that on more than just a product or two in terms of from scratch to internal start-up and Don, we're seeing that in your area. We're seeing that in Marthin De Beer's area. We are seeing it pretty much globally.

We will if you were to say all right now, where are you going to be aggressive? We are going to be aggressive in the data center. No surprises there, the data center virtualization will start first and it will go all the way to the home. We are going to be aggressive in the consumer outside of the house. And Ned doesn't have a blank check but he has a pretty good open pocket book and if you watch what the consumer did, it was that good first step. We brought out a new generation of products. You saw us capture a larger share of available spend from our customers with that product and we did it at the same margins. So we're beginning to take small steps, Ned, versus where we need to go overall.

But I'm hard pressed to say that as you begin to play through this scenario, that we aren't stronger in both our acquisition opportunities, our internal start-ups, our expansion of existing markets breaking commercial into small business, focus on small where we have not really done before in terms of our channels or the product capabilities, movements into new areas such as sports and entertainment and you are at the very front end of the wave on this next productivity tool collaboration and Web 2.0. And then just think about the video loads, that's what will call service providers to scale as you begin to put in the edge routers in those networks to build out huge core networks, you begin to load up the core back up and then you go through another cycle again, and by the way those edge opportunities come up just as we have our products coming to market which looks solid, and then you begin to think about the additional loads in terms of other categories we're going to move into which is a nice of saying I feel very comfortable with our 12 to 17% long-term growth modes. We'll be very transparent with the group but on factors we control or influence, I think things look very good.
Okay, great. Thank you, John, and thank you, Simona.

We have come to the end of our call, so I'd like to thank you for your questions. Cisco's next quarterly conference call which will reflect our fourth quarter fiscal year 2008 results will be on Tuesday, August 5, 2008 at 1:30 PM Pacific Time, 4:30 PM Eastern Time.

Additionally, downloadable Q3 financial statements will be available following this call, including revenue segments by product and geography and they can be found on our website in the Investor Relations section. Again, just click on the financial section of the website to access both the slides and these financial statements.

I'd like to remind you that in light of Regulation Fair Disclosure, Cisco plans to retain its longstanding policy to not comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through a public disclosure.
Please call the Investor Relations department with any follow-up questions from the call. Thank you for your participation and continued support. And this concludes our call.
